derivation.yuyuan_name: Middle English: related to Old French pantaisier 'be agitated, gasp', based on Greek phantasioun 'cause to imagine', from phantasia (see fantasy)

entry.def: If you pant, you breathe quickly and loudly with your mouth open, because you have been doing something energetic.

example.ex: She climbed rapidly until she was panting with the effort.
example.tran: 她爬得很快，结果累得气喘吁吁。

means.word_mean: 1. the noise made by a short puff of steam (as from an engine)
2. a short labored intake of breath with the mouth open;
1. breathe noisily, as when one is exhausted;

sentences.sentence: "The runners reached the finish line, panting heavily"

means.word_mean: 2. utter while panting, as if out of breath

Sentence.sentence: If we ask Americans why they eat with knives and forks, or why their men wear pants instead of skirts, or why they may be married to only one person at a time, we are likely to get similar and very uninformative answers: "Because it's right.
Would you like to see those pants in brown and navy blue?
Grey pants made from pure cotton
Do you think you'll be able to get this ink stain out of my pants?
Cleaning the pants will take longer than usual

sentences.en: The little boy was panting after the others.
sentences.cn: 小男孩气喘吁吁地跟在别人后头。
